title: Datasets in the STARTS Package — data.starts
text: data.starts01a. resimulated dataset containing three factors Big5 scale measured five time points used Luedtke, Robitzsch Wagner (2018). dataset contains observations without missing data. 'data.frame':   890 obs.  16 variables:  $ id: int  100006 100008 100010 100014 100032 100033 100035 100038 100049 100050 ...  $ E1: num  -0.28 1.48 0.12 -1.05 -0.28 ...  $ E2: num  0.12 -0.092 0.495 -0.679 -0.467 ...  $ E3: num  1.08 0.12 0.12 -1.27 -0.28 ...  $ E4: num  0.495 0.12 1.294 -2.229 -0.28 ...  $ E5: num  -0.092 0.707 0.707 -2.041 -0.092 ...  $ N1: num  1.114 -0.173 -0.017 0.958 1.27 ...  $ N2: num  -0.348 0.003 -1.167 1.602 1.758 ...  $ N3: num  -0.192 0.471 -0.348 1.114 0.627 ...  $ N4: num  -0.348 -1.167 -0.504 1.426 1.27 ...  $ N5: num  -0.192 -0.836 -0.192 2.421 1.27 ...  $ O1: num  1.994 -1.82 -0.107 -0.678 -0.792 ...  $ O2: num  1.423 -0.678 -0.678 -0.678 1.423 ...  $ O3: num  1.423 -1.066 -0.678 0.075 0.852 ...  $ O4: num  -0.29 -0.678 -0.29 0.075 -0.107 ...  $ O5: num  1.217 -1.637 -0.29 -0.678 0.646 ... data.starts01b. Like data.starts01a, dataset also contains cases missing data. 'data.frame':   3215 obs.  17 variables:  $ id  : int  100001 100002 100003 100004 100005 100006 100007 100008 100009 100010 ...  $ patt: Factor w/ 26 levels "P00010","P00011",..: 24 19 20 25 22 26 18 26 19 26 ...  $ E1  : num  0.308 1.67 0.308 0.308 -0.468 ...  $ E2  : num  0.308 0.895 0.707 0.707 0.12 0.12 NA -0.092 -0.28 0.496 ...  $ E3  : num  0.895 NA NA 0.895 NA ...  $ E4  : num  NA NA NA 0.496 0.496 ...  $ E5  : num  0.707 NA 0.308 NA 0.496 -0.092 -0.28 0.707 NA 0.707 ...  $ N1  : num  0.783 -0.017 -0.192 -0.017 -0.504 ...  $ N2  : num  1.114 -0.348 -0.348 -0.348 -0.836 ...  $ N3  : num  -0.348 NA NA -0.348 NA ...  $ N4  : num  NA NA NA -0.504 -1.811 ...  $ N5  : num  0.471 NA -0.192 NA -1.421 ...  $ O1  : num  -0.495 -0.107 -0.495 1.035 -0.792 ...  $ O2  : num  -0.107 -0.107 -0.29 1.035 -0.29 ...  $ O3  : num  0.464 NA NA 1.423 NA ...  $ O4  : num  NA NA NA 1.423 0.281 ...  $ O5  : num  0.646 NA -1.066 NA 0.281 ... data.starts02 contrains means covariance matrices study Wu (2016) older younger cohort (Table 2). Variables indicate item parcels  negative attitude factor six occasions. Variable b denotes  performance difficulty factor variable c somatic factor. List 2  $ older_cohort  :List 3   ..$ nobs  : num 630   ..$ mean  : Named num [1:18] 3.53 3.46 3.12 2.71 2.8 2.67 2.62 2.69 2.46 2.37 ...   .. ..- attr(*, "names")=chr [1:18] "a1" "a2" "a3" "a4" ...   ..$ covmat:'data.frame':      18 obs.  18 variables:  $ younger_cohort:List 3   ..$ nobs  : num 660   ..$ mean  : Named num [1:18] 4.62 4.52 4.46 3.58 3.96 3.21 2.94 3.16 3.03 2.74 ...   .. ..- attr(*, "names")=chr [1:18] "a1" "a2" "a3" "a4" ...   ..$ covmat:'data.frame':      18 obs.  18 variables: data.starts03a contains data Wagner, Luedtke Trautwein (2016) total sample. data.starts03b contains covariance matrices gender groups. data.starts03c contains covariance matrices groups different levels depression. structure data.starts03a List 2  $ nobs  : num 4532  $ covmat: num [1:6, 1:6] 0.236 0.164 0.147 0.129 0.13 ...   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List 2   .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...   .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ... structure data.starts03b List 2  $ female:List 2   ..$ nobs  : num 2495   ..$ covmat: num [1:6, 1:6] 0.22 0.158 0.139 0.18 0.116 ...   .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List 2   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...  $ male  :List 2   ..$ nobs  : num 2037   ..$ covmat: num [1:6, 1:6] 0.25 0.165 0.152 0.13 0.147 ...   .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List 2   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ... structure data.starts03c List 2  $ high:List 2   ..$ nobs  : num 1342   ..$ covmat: num [1:6, 1:6] 0.24 0.172 0.153 0.191 0.127 ...   .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List 2   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...  $ low :List 2   ..$ nobs  : num 1742   ..$ covmat: num [1:6, 1:6] 0.213 0.12 0.118 0.109 0.12 ...   .. ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List 2   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...   .. .. ..$ : chr [1:6] "T1" "T2" "T3" "T4" ...

title: Datasets in the STARTS Package — data.starts
text: Luedtke, O., Robitzsch, ., & Wagner, J. (2018). stable estimation STARTS model: Bayesian approach using Markov Chain Monte Carlo techniques. Psychological Methods, 23(3), 570-593. doi:10.1037/met0000155 Wagner, J., Luedtke, O., & Trautwein, U. (2016). Self-esteem mostly stable across young adulthood: Evidence latent STARTS models. Journal Personality, 84(4), 523-535. doi:10.1111/jopy.12178 Wu, P.-C. (2016). Longitudinal stability Beck Depression Inventory II: latent trait-state-occasion model. Journal Psychoeducational Assessment, 34, 39-53. doi:10.1177/0734282915582101

what: Functions for the STARTS Model — STARTS-package
title: Functions for the STARTS Model — STARTS-package
text: Contains functions estimating STARTS model     Kenny Zautra (1995, 2001) <DOI:10.1037/0022-006X.63.1.52>,     <DOI:10.1037/10409-008>. Penalized maximum likelihood     estimation Markov Chain Monte Carlo estimation     also provided, see Luedtke, Robitzsch Wagner (2018)      <DOI:10.1037/met0000155>.

title: Functions for the STARTS Model — STARTS-package
text: Alexander Robitzsch [aut,cre] (<https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8226-3132>),   Oliver Luedtke [aut] (<https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9744-3059>) Maintainer: Alexander Robitzsch <robitzsch@ipn.uni-kiel.de>

title: Functions for the STARTS Model — STARTS-package
text: Kenny, D. ., & Zautra, . (1995). trait-state-error model multiwave data. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 63, 52-59. doi:10.1037/0022-006X.63.1.52 Kenny, D. ., & Zautra, . (2001). Trait-state models  longitudinal data. L. M. Collins & . G. Sayer (Eds.),  New methods analysis change (pp. 243-263). Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association. doi:10.1037/10409-008 Luedtke, O., Robitzsch, ., & Wagner, J. (2018). stable estimation STARTS model: Bayesian approach using Markov Chain Monte Carlo techniques. Psychological Methods, 23(3), 570-593. doi:10.1037/met0000155

what: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
title: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
text: Functions computing covariance matrix simulating data univariate STARTS model (Kenny & Zautra, 1995, 2001). STARTS model can estimated maximum likelihood, penalized maximum likelihood (.e., maximum posterior estimation) Markov Chain Monte Carlo. See Luedtke, Robitzsch Wagner (2018) comparisons among estimation methods.

title: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
code: ## estimation of univariate STARTS model starts_uni_estimate(data=NULL, covmat=NULL, nobs=NULL, estimator="ML",     pars_inits=NULL, prior_var_trait=c(3, 0.33), prior_var_ar=c(3, 0.33),     prior_var_state=c(3, 0.33), prior_a=c(3, 0.5), est_var_trait=TRUE,     est_var_ar=TRUE, est_var_state=TRUE, var_meas_error=0, constraints=TRUE,     time_index=NULL, type="stationary", n.burnin=5000, n.iter=20000,     verbose=FALSE, optim_fct="optim", use_rcpp=TRUE )  # S3 method for starts_uni summary(object, digits=3, file=NULL, print_call=TRUE, ...)  # S3 method for starts_uni plot(x, ...)  # S3 method for starts_uni logLik(object, ...)  # S3 method for starts_uni coef(object, ...)  # S3 method for starts_uni vcov(object, ...)  ## computation of covariance matrix starts_uni_cov(W, var_trait, var_ar, var_state, a, time_index=NULL,        add_meas_error=NULL)  ## simulation of STARTS model starts_uni_sim(N, W, var_trait, var_ar, var_state, a, time_index=NULL )  #--- deprecated functions starts_cov(W, var_trait, var_ar, var_state, a) starts_sim1dim(N, W, var_trait, var_ar, var_state, a )

title: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
text: data Data frame. Missing data must coded NA. covmat Covariance matrix (necessary data provided) nobs Number observations (necessary data provided) estimator Type estimator: "ML" maximum likelihood estimation (using LAM::pmle), "PML" penalized maximum likelihood estimation (using LAM::pmle) "MCMC" Markov chain Monte Carlo estimation (using LAM::amh). pars_inits Optional vector initial parameters prior_var_trait Vector length two specifying inverse gamma prior trait variance. first entry prior sample size, second entry guess proportion variance attributed trait variance. See Luedtke et al. (2018) details. prior_var_ar Prior autoregressive variance. See prior_var_trait details. prior_var_state Prior state variance. See prior_var_trait details. prior_a Vector length two specification beta prior stability parameter . first entry corresponds prior sample size, second entry corresponds prior guess stability parameter. est_var_trait Logical indicating whether trait variance estimated. est_var_ar Logical indicating whether autoregressive variance estimated. est_var_state Logical indicating whether state variance estimated. var_meas_error Value known measurement variance. based reliability estimate internal consistency, example. constraints Logical indicating whether variances constrained positive time_index Integer vector time indices. Time points can non-equidistant, must integer values. type Type starts model. "stationary" implemented package version. n.burnin Number burn-iterations (estimator="MCMC") n.iter Total number iterations (estimator="MCMC") verbose Logical indicating whether iteration progress displayed (estimator="ML" estimator="PML") optim_fct Type optimization function estimator="ML" estimator="PML". Can "optim" stats::optim "nlminb" stats::nlminb. use_rcpp Logical indicating whether Rcpp code used estimation. W Number measurement waves. var_trait Variance trait component. var_ar Variance autoregressive component. var_state Variance state component. N Sample size persons Stability parameter object Object class starts_uni digits Number digits decimal summary output file Optional file name summary output print_call Logical indicating whether call printed summary output x Object class starts_uni ... arguments passed. plot method, see plot method LAM::amh function arguments add_meas_error Optional vector measurement error variance added diagonal covariance matrix.

title: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
text: Output starts_uni_estimate coef Vector estimated parameters ... values Output starts_uni_cov covariance matrix. Output starts_uni_sim data frame containing simulated values.

title: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
text: Kenny, D. ., & Zautra, . (1995). trait-state-error model multiwave data. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 63, 52-59. doi:10.1037/0022-006X.63.1.52 Kenny, D. ., & Zautra, . (2001). Trait-state models longitudinal data. L. M. Collins & . G. Sayer (Eds.), New methods analysis change (pp. 243-263). Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association. doi:10.1037/10409-008 Luedtke, O., Robitzsch, ., & Wagner, J. (2018). stable estimation STARTS model: Bayesian approach using Markov Chain Monte Carlo techniques. Psychological Methods, 23(3), 570-593. doi:10.1037/met0000155

title: Functions for the Univariate STARTS Model — starts_uni
code: library(sirt)  ############################################################################# # EXAMPLE 1: STARTS model specification using starts_uni_estimate #############################################################################  ## use simulated dataset according to Luedtke et al. (2017)  data(data.starts01a, package="STARTS") dat <- data.starts01a  #--- covariance matrix and number of observations covmat <- stats::cov( dat[, paste0("E",1:5) ] ) nobs <- nrow(dat)  #*** Model 1a: STARTS model with ML estimation mod1a <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs) summary(mod1a)  if (FALSE) { #- estimate model based on input data mod1a1 <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( data=dat[, paste0("E",1:5) ]) summary(mod1a1)  #*** Model 1b: STARTS model with penalized ML estimation using the default priors mod1b <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs, estimator="PML") summary(mod1b)  #*** Model 1c: STARTS model with MCMC estimation and default priors set.seed(987) mod1c <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs, estimator="MCMC")  # assess convergence plot(mod1c) # summary summary(mod1c) # extract more information logLik(mod1c) coef(mod1c) vcov(mod1c)  #*** Model 1d: MCMC estimation with different prior distributions mod1d <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs, estimator="MCMC",              prior_var_trait=c(10, 0.5), prior_var_ar=c(10, 0.3),              prior_var_state=c(10, 0.2), prior_a=c(1, 0.5) ) summary(mod1d)  #*** Model 2: remove autoregressive process mod2 <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs, est_var_ar=FALSE) summary(mod2)  #*** Model 3: remove stable trait factor mod3 <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs, est_var_trait=FALSE) summary(mod3)  #*** Model 4: remove state variance from the model mod4 <- STARTS::starts_uni_estimate( covmat=covmat, nobs=nobs, est_var_state=FALSE) summary(mod4) }
